items.title: Landlords sue Jersey City over plan to give tenants free legal help
items.description: The Jersey City Property Owners’ Association says the new "right to counsel" program exceeds the city's authority.

image.title: shutterstock_1029430792.jpg
image.alt: Male lawyer working with contract papers and wooden gavel on tabel in courtroom
image.caption: Jersey City plans to launch a "right to counsel" program, where tenants will have access to free legal representation in disputes with landlords.

related_authors.biography: Karen Yi covers New Jersey and started in the newsroom in 2020. Before joining WNYC, Karen covered Newark for the Star-Ledger and spent almost a decade working for newspapers in New Jersey and Florida. She grew up in Miami and has a dog named Cashew. Got a tip? Email kyi@wnyc.org or Signal 917-589-1460.

items.title: Affordable housing at 5 World Trade Center approved by state board
items.description: Roughly a third of the 1,200 homes planned for 5 World Trade Center will be reserved for moderate- to low-income residents.

image.title: 5WTC [Rendering]
image.alt: A rendering of Five World Trade Center at 130 Liberty Street in Lower Manhattan.
image.caption: A rendering of Five World Trade Center at 130 Liberty Street in Lower Manhattan.

items.title: Search called off for teen who went missing off Coney Island beach
items.description: The NYPD said another teen was found in stable condition, but divers were unable to locate the missing boy.

image.title: Parks
image.alt: General view of Coney Island Beach in New York officially opens its doors on Saturday, May 27, 2023.
image.caption: General view of Coney Island Beach in New York officially opens its doors on Saturday, May 27, 2023.

related_authors.biography: Ramsey is a day-of news intern at Gothamist and WNYC.

items.title: Extra Extra: Poppin' champagne at the Manhattan Wegmans
items.description: Because curb your dog signs have to be creative to be seen, here are your afternoon links: a bougie Wegmans, nonconsensual organ harvesting, X's are the new tweets, and more.

image.title: Wegman's opening in Brooklyn
image.alt: Scenes from opening day of the new Brooklyn Wegman's

items.title: 'Renaissance' fare: 5 ways to celebrate Beyoncé coming to NJ this weekend
items.description: Whether you scored tickets for Beyoncé's two concerts at MetLife Stadium or you'll be sitting at home looking for livestreams, you can get into the mood at these five celebratory events.

image.title: GettyImages-1564411180.jpg
image.alt: A busy concert stage with a singer dressed in silver poised high overhead
image.caption: Whether you're seeing Beyoncé perform live in New Jersey this weekend or not, there are plenty of options for celebrating her arrival.

related_authors.biography: Precious is a culture and arts reporter covering the diverse arts community around New York City. Got a tip? Email pfondren@nypublicradio.org or Signal 646-988-9525.

items.title: Supervisors at a Bronx juvenile detention center charged with punching and stomping teen detainee
items.description: Federal prosecutors say the men then took steps to cover up the attack.

image.alt: The Horizon Juvenile Center in the Bronx.

items.title: NYC is under an 'Excessive Heat Warning' as 3-day heat wave begins
items.description: Mayor Adams urged residents to stay safe: “Heat kills more New Yorkers every year than any other kind of extreme weather event.”

image.title: GettyImages-1413871449.jpg
image.alt: A man walks outside in the heat.

related_authors.biography: Brittany Kriegstein covers all breaking news around New York City, with a focus on crime and gun violence. Got a tip? Email Brittany at bkriegstein@nypublicradio.org.

items.title: 25 free things to do in NYC this August
items.description: There's something suited to every taste happening free of charge almost every day in New York City, from world-class theater, concerts and dance to outdoor film screenings and exercise classes.

image.title: Beach Sessions Dance Series.jpg
image.alt: A small group of costumed dancers leading a large crowd along a beach
image.caption: The Beach Sessions Dance Series returns to Rockaway Beach on August 26.

related_authors.biography: Steve Smith came to WNYC from NPR, where he served as a senior editor on the Arts Desk. He ostensibly focused on music coverage, but in reality handled subjects like Mickey Mouse's creator, AI voice cloning, and even the 50th anniversary of the Crock Pot. Steve served previously as a music editor at Time Out New York, a classical-music critic for The New York Times, a weekly contributor to The New Yorker, and an assistant arts editor at the Boston Globe. He lives in Jackson Heights, Queens, with his wife, journalist and scholar Lara Pellegrinelli (herself a past contributor to WNYC and NPR), their daughter, and two dogs. Got a tip? Email stsmith@nypublicradio.org or Signal 917-938-4043.

items.title: Early Addition: NY lawmakers want the 5-0 to stop the 4-20 in the park
items.description: Because taxi drivers need that respite, here are your early links: a push to stop cannabis smoking in public, NYC's hidden bookstores, volunteer craft finishers and more from around the city and internet.

items.title: Safe to swim? Play outside? How to keep NYC kids (and adults) healthy during this heat wave.
items.listing_title: An expert on ways to stay safe and healthy in the heat
items.description: As sweltering temperatures hit the New York region, an emergency medicine professor from Columbia University offers tips on how to spot the signs of heat stress and heatstroke.

image.title: 20230725_hottest nabes_GettyImages-1552544441.jpg
image.alt: New Yorkers visit a water fountain on July 24, 2023 to get relief from a streak of hot weather.
image.caption: New Yorkers visit a water fountain on July 24, 2023 to get relief from a streak of hot weather.
image.credit: Fatih Aktas/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images

related_authors.biography:
Nsikan runs the health and science desk at WNYC/Gothamist. Nsikan was previously at National Geographic where he worked as a science editor, overseeing its COVID-19 coverage in addition to other topics in science, health and technology. Before National Geographic, he worked for more than four years at PBS NewsHour, where he co-created an award-winning video series named ScienceScope. 

He shared a 2020 Emmy for the PBS NewsHour series “Stopping a Killer Pandemic” and in 2019 received a George Foster Peabody Award for the PBS NewsHour series “The Plastic Problem.” Nsikan has also worked for NPR, Science News Magazine, Science Magazine, KUSP Central Coast Public Radio, the Santa Cruz Sentinel and as a writer at the Center for Infection and Immunity at Columbia University. He holds a doctorate in pathobiology from Columbia University and is an alum of the science communication program at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

items.title: New York lawmakers vow insurance industry crackdown after Gothamist investigation
items.description: The lawmakers said they will introduce bills prohibiting insurers from asking landlords whether they accept tenants with housing vouchers and denying coverage for subsidized housing.

image.title: GettyImages-1394257889.jpg
image.alt: Assembly member Linda Rosenthal holds a megaphone up to her mouth during a housing protest in City Hall Park.
image.caption: “This kind of behavior cements decades-old stereotypes and we should have moved away from that kind of practices years ago,” said Assemblymember Linda Rosenthal (D-Manhattan) said. “It's really reprehensible.”
image.credit: Photo by Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images

related_authors.biography: David is a reporter covering housing for Gothamist and WNYC. Got a tip? Email dbrand@nypublicradio.org or Signal 908-310-3960.

items.title: NYC is not enforcing a law prohibiting stores from air conditioning the streets
items.description: Amid a global climate crisis, buildings are pumping AC onto the streets to lure customers inside.

value.caption: Businesses that leave their doors open during summer are not getting fined.

related_authors.biography: Charles is a Day-of reporter focused on breaking news and enterprise. He’s very friendly and can be reached at charles@wnyc.org, or more securely on whatsapp/signal 631-295-6715
